_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

C.W. Resources, Inc. (CWR) is committed to protecting the health and safety of company personnel, contractors working at the West Tyler Gas Processing Plant (facility), our neighbors in the surrounding community and the environment.  This commitment is strongly supported by the senior management of CWR and is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training, and in considering the design safety, installation, operation, and maintenance of this facility.  This facility implements both administrative and engineering controls to reasonably minimize the risk of an uncontrolled release of a hazardous substance.  The facility does not anticipate having any type of uncontrolled release.  However, if an uncontrolled release does occur, company personnel, in cooperation with local emergency response agencies, are trained to respond, minimize and/or eliminate any exposure that could occur to protect employees and the surrounding area.  



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Tyler Gas Processing Plant is a natural gas processing plant that produces liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) by mechanical refrigeration.  Natural gas piped to this facility is dehydrated, cooled and the contaminants removed.  The LPG, a mixture of methane, ethane, propane, butanes, pentanes, hexanes and C6+ compounds, is stored in a pressurized bullet tank for transportation by truck.  Condensate and produced water removed from the gas stream is stored in a separate tank for transport from the site via tanker trucks.  No listed toxic substances which exceed their respective threshold quantities are stored at this facility.



Hazard Assessment - Worst Case Scenario

The Worst-Case Scenario for this facility is failure of the LPG storage tank releasing the entire contents instantaneously to the atmosphere, resulting in an offsite impact radius of 0.6 mile.  The Environmental Pr

otection Agency's (EPA's) RMP*Comp was used to calculate this release scenario.  This type of scenario is very unlikely to occur.  In addition, qualified individuals inspect this facility on a regular basis, inspecting and maintaining the equipment according to a preventive maintenance schedule further reducing the likelihood of a worst-case scenario.



Accidental Release Prevention Program

This facility is regulated by 29 CFR 1910.110 Occupational Safety and Health Standards, Subpart H, Storage and Handling of liquified petroleum gases;  (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals), 1910.38 (Employee Emergency Plans), 1910.120 (Hazardous Waste and Emergency Response), 40 CFR 112 (Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure), RCRA and State and Federal EPCRA rules/laws, as well as other federal, state, and local regulations, which are all developed to reduce the potential for the release of highly hazardous chemicals.  Facility accident prevention programs promote the proactive identification, evaluation, and mitigation or prevention of releases of highly hazardous substances that could occur as a result of failures in processes, procedures, or equipment.  



An established comprehensive training program has been developed and implemented for this facility.  All employees are trained in an overview of the processes as well as in appropriate safe work practices per the corporate safety guidelines.  In addition to the general training required of all employees, personnel having operation and maintenance procedural responsibilities at this facility are further trained in those procedures.



Safe work practices have been developed to ensure safe operations that are consistent with industry practice and meet regulatory requirements.  Safe work practices include site control, lockout/tagout, line breaking, confined space entry and hot work to ensure the safety and well being of employees and the surrounding area.



CWR has a policy of investigating every

incident, which may have possibly resulted in a release to prevent a similar accident from recurring.  They have also established an audit procedure to assure the continued integrity of the prevention program, and to ensure the safety and well being of employees and the surrounding area.



5 Year Accident History

The Tyler Gas Processing Plant has had an excellent accident prevention program over the last five years.  There have been no releases of listed hazardous substances which resulted in offsite effects.



Emergency Response Program

The Tyler Gas Processing Plant has adopted and maintains a written emergency response plan to protect workers, ensure public safety and to protect the environment.  The plan details the procedures for responding to an emergency, including the release or potential release of a hazardous substance.  The procedures include instruction for response, communication, first aid, evacuation, accounting for personnel, company and agency notification procedures, and post incident cleanup and decontamination.  All emergency equipment is maintained following established procedures.  Employees are trained in the procedures and use of equipment appropriate to their role in the response effort.  The emergency response plan is coordinated with the local emergency responders such as local law enforcement, local and state government officials, and the local emergency planning committee.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

CWR personnel continue to develop new ways to improve the safety of the facility.  This is done through responsibility matrices and training which is a vital part of any safety program.  Training is conducted according to a systematic schedule so employees and contractors are given the most up to date programs in the industry.  All new and modified equipment is designed with appropriate safety controls and devices.
